Master this ultimate upper glute exercise 🍑

ONLY feeling your low back? If you’re doing 45 degree glute raises and always feeling only your low back, this post is for YOU👇

The main reason why you’re feeling your low back is because your range of motion is too long. A 45 degree glute raise has a short range of motion and you’re only coming up high enough to shorten the glutes which is about parallel. 

You want a neutral spine throughout, not an arch at the top. ✅ 

Also to feel more glutes you want to bent your knees slightly to disadvantage hamstrings a bit and turn your toes out to help with the shortening of the glutes✅

Now if your goal is more low back, you’d want a longer range of motion. But if it’s more glutes, it’s a shorter range of motion. 

Save this post for the next time you’re doing 45’s at the gym✅

Cable step ups are absolutely a booty burner when executed properly. 

The first execution is going to be more quads. I have a more upright torso, I am moving up/down and I have a greater degree of knee flexion thus making it more quads.

To make a step up more glutes…

You’re going to want to lean forward and push your butt back. We want to minimize knee flexion and maximize hip flexion. Hold the weight on your working leg side so you’re not having to brace against the load. I also recommend holding onto something stable with the opposite hand to really focus on pushing your butt back and lengthening the glute rather than trying to prevent yourself from falling over👌

Make these changes to get more booty out of your step ups🍑

Everyone talks about protein for muscle growth, but what about carbs?🍎🍞

If you want to MAXIMIZE muscle growth, keto is NOT optimal. 

The data seems to show that keto is beneficial for fat loss (but not necessarily better than other diets when calories are the same) and happens at a faster rate short term due to glycogen depletion and water loss BUT keto diets do not appear to be beneficial for building muscle mass. Maintenance and fat loss? Yes. Growth? No.

Carbs are needed for energy and for performance. The body can extract much greater energy from carbs than it can from fat. Carbs are also needed for muscle growth because if you’re low on glycogen, during your training this can create a reduction in motor unit recruitment but also it appears it plays a part in excitation contraction coupling failure which means the fibers will not experience mechanical tension (the mechanism that causes this is unknown). 

We have several studies that show that you can’t maximize muscle growth on keto, only maintain.

PMID: 29986720 looked at the difference between keto and non-keto diets in resistance trained men doing an 8 week resistance training program. It concluded that keto is beneficial for decreasing fat mass while preserving muscle mass but not useful for building muscle mass. 

PMID: 20196854 looked at the effects of keto in overweight, untrained women and found that the keto diet decreases fat mass without significantly changing lean body mass. Resistance training on a non-keto diet may increasing lean body mass. The fact that untrained women didn’t gain muscle mass while doing 10 weeks resistance training is crazy, as newbie gains are a real thing and it’s much easier for a newbie to build lean tissue. 

If you want to maximize muscle growth, keto isn’t it. If you want to maximize fat loss, keto is beneficial. But also likely isn’t any better than other diets when calories are equated. 

And for those that may be curious, it is speculated to be about >3g of carbs per kg of body weight if you want to MAXIMIZE muscle growth. 💪

SLDL VS. RDL👇

Two totally different exercises!

➡️An RDL has a slightly bent knee in order to disadvantage the hamstrings, making it more glute dominant. The bent knee puts the hamstrings into active insufficiency so they cannot contribute as much. There will still be some hamstrings in an RDL. 

➡️An SLDL has a straight knee which makes it more hamstring dominant. You’ll still get some glutes as well.

You can FEEL the difference when you go from a bent knee to as straight knee and vice versa. 

Both are great exercises. Choose the one that aligns best with your goals! Or do both (different days though).

Here’s why women don’t need to train differently than men👇

In 63 studies the average strength gain for men was 29.41%.

For women it was 37.42%.

In 53 studies looking at muscle growth men and women gained muscle at nearly the same rate.

Women don’t need to do high reps light weight and tons of isolation exercises.

They need to do the same thing men do to grow muscle. 

➡️Moderate volume 
➡️Heavy sets of 6-8
➡️Longer rest periods between sets 

Source: https://www.strongerbyscience.com/strength-training-women/

THE BEST GLUTE MEDIUS EXERCISE‼️

This study (PMID: 19574661) found that the side-lying hip abduction had the greatest glute medius activity, even compared to clams, lunges and other single leg exercises. 

“Gluteus medius activity was significantly greater during side-lying hip abduction (mean +/- SD, 81% +/- 42% MVIC) compared to the 2 types of hip clam (40% +/- 38% MVIC, 38% +/- 29% MVIC), lunges (48% +/- 21% MVIC), and hop (48% +/- 25% MVIC) exercises” PMID: 19574661.

“The best exercise for the gluteus medius was side-lying hip abduction” PMID: 19574661.

Now this make sense as the glute medius has an abduction component and also, this exercise reduces any output from the non-working leg as it doesn’t need to stabilize. Therefore, we can focus on the working leg and get maximal from the glute medius. 

You can also do this with cables. I do like that the band tension increases as you lift the leg, challenging the glutes where they are the strongest. 

I have this exercise in a band and cable variation in the app🔥

Add it into your training!🙌🏻

Contrary to popular belief, longer rest periods are actually better for hypertrophy, 3 minutes between working sets, than shorter rest periods, less than 1 minute. 

It’s been shown that training with shorter rest periods produces less hypertrophy and this is likely due to the CNS fatigue doesn’t have enough time to go away after the set. Also if the following set takes place too soon after the previous, you won’t be able to recruit as many high threshold motor units for that set. 

Study #1- Volume Load Rather Than Resting Interval Influences Muscle Hypertrophy During High-Intensity Resistance Training 
➡️Had 28 untrained subjects train 2x per week for 10 weeks. One group did 3 sets to failure with 3 min rest periods and the other did 3 sets to failure 1 min rest periods. 
Results➡️It showed that the group that trained with SHORTER rest periods had less hypertrophy than the group with longer rest periods. 
PMID: 35622106.

Study #2-Longer Interset Rest Periods Enhance Muscle Strength and Hypertrophy in Resistance-Trained Men
➡️Had 21 resistance trained individuals that trained full body 3x per week for 8 weeks. One group had 1 minute rest periods and the other had 3 minute rest periods. 
Results➡️ “Maximal strength was significantly greater for both 1RM squat and bench press for LONG compared to SHORT. Muscle thickness was significantly greater for LONG compared to SHORT in the anterior thigh, and a trend for greater increases was noted in the triceps brachii (p = 0.06) as well” (Schoenfeld, 2016). 
PMID: 26605807

So this is why I am always programming 3-5 min rest prior to a working set and then warm-up sets are about 60 to 90 seconds. Rest is important! I get it, I don’t love it either but if you really want to maximize hypertrophy, it’s NEEDED!

It’s not every set and you won’t be in the gym for hours, especially if you’re choosing quality over quantity.

WHAT REP RANGE DO YOU PREFER AND WHY?👇

I used to do a lot of 4x12, 4x15 etc. I even used to program a lot like this. And what I found was that likely when you tell someone to do 3 or 4 sets of the same rep range, they’re more likely to use the SAME weight throughout the exercise.

It’s also less likely they’ll go to failure. Now this is something I have found from experience but it makes sense. 

You’re given the same amount of reps for every single set, it’s likely there won’t be large jumps in weight. And it’s likely they’ll stop at the amount of reps provided, whether it was challenging or not. 

I now do and program descending reps where the first 2-3 sets are going to be your warm-ups as you aren’t going to failure on these sets. The reps are decreasing each set so you’ll want to increase the weight each set. This is preparing you for that last final set that you will take close to failure or to failure. I program 1 of these sets, some people will do 2. Just remember more sets = more fatigue so more isn’t better. 

Instead of sticking to 12-15 reps, drop your working sets to 5-8 reps. I’ve even been incorporating 4 reps to lessen fatigue! Your warm up sets can be higher reps but be sure that as you get to those heavier working sets, that you’re using heavier weights and lower rep ranges for better results and more growth 🤌

During my first few years of lifting, I probably never repeated a workout. I would have certain movements I’d repeat but I was always incorporating new movements and never sticking to the same ones for a period of time. 

Now, I stick to the same movements most of the time and make some changes here and there. 

By doing this, I can actually see that I’m making progress by repeating the same exercises, tracking my workouts and working to add reps/weights over time. 

Yes, this may be boring to some but good, quality training is not going to always be fun. If you truly want to make progress, stick to the same exercises for a period of time, track your sets/reps and work to get stronger over time 💪

This is called progressive overload and it can’t be done if you’re always changing up your workouts and never actually giving yourself time to improve on certain movements. 💪

Choose movements you enjoy doing and REPEAT THEM. 6-8 weeks is a good timeframe for progressive overload to occur but you honestly don’t have to change it up at all. I keep a lot of movements the same and change out some of the movements I’m doing after a couple months. Overall, my workouts are always very repetitive.

You don’t need to do 8-10 exercises to make progress‼️

I used to have the belief that more is better and that you need to do 8+ exercises to make progress.

And I was wrong. 

This many exercises accumulates excess fatigue which contributes to more muscle damage and a longer recovery. 

There comes a point where more volume is actually going to hurt, not help. 

Rather than doing 8-10 exercises, pick 4-6 and do a couple warm up sets and then have your last set be a set to failure or close to it. When you decrease your volume, increase your rest times and train to failure, you can get the same results if not better, compared to high volume/short rest.

I guarantee your training and recovery will improve.

Example…
First 2-3 sets = Increasing weight each set, decreasing reps, sticking to 8-12 reps for these sets. 
Last set- Heaviest and hardest set, to failure or close to it and around 5-7 reps. 

I noticed my recovery was better, my training sessions were better and my ability to progressively overload improved. 

I was able to train harder doing LESS and spending far less time in the gym, getting the same results if not better doing half the volume.

Let’s talk redundant exercise selections👇

I often get asked if certain exercise pairings are redundant…

And most of the time, my answer is yes. 

If you’re doing different variations of the same movement in a workout, this is redundant. 

I often see multiple different RDL variations in 1 workout which is not only redundant but also incredibly fatiguing as RDL’s are a lengthened movement. 

Movements like a split squat and a step up are also redundant as they’re very similar movements. You’re going from a flexed hip and knee to an extended hip and knee while training the glutes in a lengthened position. 

Different variations of the same movement are redundant and also very similar movements with the same joint positions are redundant. 

To maximize muscle growth, choose a variety of different movements that train the different segments/regions of the muscle and train it in different positions, rather than repeating the same position over and over.

Here’s an example of a quality glute day (similar to my app programs) that would not entail any repetitive movements and also train the glutes in different positions/train all the different regions. 

1. Hip thrust (short position-upper) 
2. Kickback (short- glute medius/upper) 
3. RDL (lengthened-lower) 
4. Bulgarian split squat (lengthened- lower and also trains the glute medius depending on the stability needed)

3 band exercises for UPPER GLUTES🍑 

Here are 3 killer band exercises to target your upper glutes. These can be used as finishers or added into your routine. Don’t underestimate the power of a band! 

1. Glute medius internal rotation
This will target the anterior fibers as they do hip internal rotation. Use a band around your ankles, have your feet together and think of rotating your heels outwards towards the walls. 

2. Side lying hip abduction 
These are KILLER. I highly recommend using a bench and securing the band under the bench, that way you’re not have to think of keeping your non-working leg down. 

3. Prone kickbacks 

This was also a killer one and they’re great without a band as well. But try adding the band for an extra challenge! Keep your knees bent and think of driving your feet towards the ceiling. 

The first two are in my app and I’ll be adding the third today 🔥

A few common mistakes I see with cable RDL’s are that people stand too close to the cable machine and allow the cable to pull them straight down, rather than pushing their butt back. 

Here are a few tips… 

1. Use dual handles if possible. 

2. Stand further back from the cable. 

3. Bend your knees slightly. 

4. Think of pushing your butt back towards the wall behind you. 

Cable RDL’s are a great RDL variation to target both the upper and lower glutes by changing the resistance profile and standing further away from the cable🥳

SHOULD YOU SQUEEZE YOUR GLUTES AT THE TOP? WHICH MOVEMENTS⁉️✅❌ 

This is a common question I get in regards to certain movements, if you should thrust in and squeeze your glutes at the top.

There are movements where this is greatly beneficial and then there are other movements where it’s not necessary! 

Hip extension movements like glute bridges, hip thrusts and 45° Glute raises will be movements where you do want to squeeze your glutes at the top and really push into full hip extension. This is going to be where the glutes have the most leverage and it’s really optimal to get full hip extension to fully shorten the glutes. Turning your toes out on these movements can also help to do so.

When it comes to movements like squats and romanian deadlifts, it’s not optimal to squeeze your glutes/thrust in at the top. 
In an RDL or a squat, your glutes are going to be under the most tension when they are lengthened, this will be at the bottom portion of a squat and RDL. There’s nothing for the glutes to contract against. You’re just squeezing your glutes and going into lumbar extension which is going to put more pressure on your lower back.

So you’d rather keep your head, spine and pelvis neutral throughout each rep.

✅Bridges/thrusts 
✅ 45° glute raise
✅Kickbacks

❌Squats 
❌RDL/good morning

If you’re constantly sliding back during glute bridges, this video is for you!

I love glute bridges and they’re a great upper glute max exercise but it is constantly a struggle to keep myself in place and not slide back each rep😡

A quick fix for this is to use a Bosu ball and rest your shoulder blades on it. You can also use an aerobic step with a mat! Basically anything that is stable that will prevent you from sliding back. I find the Bosu ball works best. I also recommend putting it up against a squat rack or wall. Depending on how much weight you’re using, you may even push the Bosu back! So it’s a good idea to put it up against something that won’t move. 

Try this hack the next time you’re doing glute bridges 🍑

The most DANGEROUS way to press…

Kidding.

For real…

Stop listening to people who…

Tell you this way of pressing is bad or dangerous❌❌❌❌

So I’m sure you’ve seen a lot of posts on social media about pressing in the scapular plane and how it’s dangerous to press in this highly abducted position.

But is this true? 

And what does it mean to press in the scapular plane and why?

The scapular plane is when you adduct the humerus 30° from the frontal plane. 

The reason why it’s more optimal to press this way is because the scapular sits anterior 30 degrees on the thoracic wall. In the scapular plane, the mechanical axis of the humerus is lined up with the mechanical axis of the scapula. 

This allows for more subacromial space and for the most natural articulation for the scapula to upwardly rotate across the thoracic wall as you raise the arms up.

But this doesn’t mean that pressing in that highly abducted position is necessarily BAD. Now if you experience shoulder pain/discomfort, it would be better for you to press in the scapular plane. 

It allows for better alignment of the humerus and scapula. There are no leverage differences between pressing in the scapular plane and the frontal plane. It is just more stable and allows for better alignment of the joints. 

So it’s not necessarily BAD to press in that highly abducted position it is just BETTER to press in the scapular plane.

I see this going around ALL the time now but with a lack of WHY we do this. So hopefully this helps you decide the best way to press! Find what works best for you and is most comfortable. I personally prefer to press in the scapular plane ❤️

I’m here to convince you to swap out the leg on the bench RDL for a b-stance RDL w/rotation✨

While it’s not BAD, there are definitely better options. 

The leg on the bench variation doesn’t really allow you to hinge properly. One of the cues people struggle with in an RDL is really pushing their glutes back. This variation makes it harder to really push your butt back and also limits how far you can push it back, before your stopped by the leg on the bench. 

You also have so much of your body weight resting on the bench. Therefore, it’s going to take using a lot more weight than a typical RDL to actually make this exercise worthwhile. 

Depending on your structure and bench height, it can be a poor option because your pelvis needs to be level. 

Instead, try the b-stance RDL w/rotation. I also like to use the wall for better stability!

The rotation here is also a benefit since the hip is a ball and socket joint, and most people lack good rotation at the hip. 

Why is this important?  Because the glutes extend the hip but we need good rotation in order to have a place to extend FROM. 

The other benefit here is that the upper glute division is lengthened a bit more in the rotation and biases it just a bit here, helping to create that “upper booty” shelf. 

But that’s not the only benefit.  The wall itself helps to train better hip flexion by creating an external point to get to with the glutes. 

So push the front leg glute (the one you are working) to the wall…don’t just bend at the waist. 

Often, people bend at the waist rather than hinging at the hips. So think of pushing your butt back to the wall and actually touch the wall.

The glute medius is a muscle that sits under the glute max and can help build that “upper glute”. 

It works to abduct (bring leg away from body) the hip and prevents the pelvis from tilting to the opposite side while standing on one leg. This means it works to stabilize while you are performing unilateral exercises. When I say you are training the stabilization component of the glute medius during unilateral work, this is what I mean. 

The glute medius have the greatest leverage to abduct the hip from 0 to about 30-45 degrees. Kickbacks and standing abductions are both great exercises to work the medius as well as the minimus, as it works as a synergist to the medius. 

When you’re doing a standing abduction or a kickback, you’re still getting a lot of work from the glute medius on the standing leg as it’s working to stabilize the pelvis. 

So if you really want to isolate the medius/minimus on your working leg, kneel on a bench! 

This and kickbacks on the bench are some of my faves for glute medius/minimus.

It’s a common myth that intensifiers like supersets, trisets, drop sets, etc. are better for muscle growth than just doing straight sets. And this is NOT true. 

While these have application, (timesavers, enjoyment factor, alleviate redundancy/boredom…) your best bet for muscle growth is always going to be straight sets where you’re progressively overloading and using proper rest. 

With intensifiers like drop sets, supersets and trisets, you’re just accumulating more fatigue in the set. This can make training less productive. 

On the second or third exercise in a drop set or superset, you’re going to have a lot of fatigue going into this exercise. Therefore, you won’t be able to train as hard, go as heavy and it will be harder to progressively overload over time, compared to doing it as a straight set. 

Now there’s a better way to implement supersets and drop sets. I personally would never recommend a tri set, there’s just waaaay too much fatigue and the goal is not to exhaust yourself in the gym. Proper rest periods are needed to hypertrophy and by the time you get to the third exercise, you’re going to be exhausted and also can increase injury risk depending on the exercise. 

For supersets and drop sets, keep the reps LOWER. So instead of doing 10+ reps in a superset on each exercise, stick to something like 4-8 to lessen fatigue. For a drop set, perform it on your last set to failure and then make small decreases in weight where you’re only getting a few reps (3-4) to increase the amount of effective reps you’re getting in that set.

When it comes to training for muscle growth, we want to keep fatigue as low as we can to allow for good recovery and to make training as productive as we can. 

So yes, intensifiers are okay to add in to your training but I would limit them and keep reps low👌

I often get asked, “why do I lose my glutes in a cut?” and how to prevent this from happening. 

There are a few reasons as to why this is occurring, but one of the main reasons is that you did not spend enough time building your glutes, so there isn’t a significant amount of muscle there. Therefore, when you cut, you lose body fat, and end up losing the fat that you have on your glutes, making your glutes look smaller.

Now this is inevitable to some degree. We all have a combination of both fat and muscle on our glutes. So when you cut, you’re going to lose some of the fact that is making your glutes appear bigger. Unless you’re just super blessed genetically.😂😂 

If you have a lot more fat than muscle on your glutes, you’re likely going to lose more than someone who has more glute muscle when cutting. 

So the key is to spend a long period of time in a surplus, focusing on growing your glutes. When I say surplus, I’m not talking about a huge bulk. It’s a common misconception that you need to 500 to 1000 cal over maintenance in order to grow. 200 to 300 is really all you need. Especially if your goal is to limit excess fat gain. 

Another thing that can lead to muscle loss in a cut is inadequate protein intake.

A study (PMID: 26817506) looked at protein intake during a caloric deficit while resistance training. They had two groups, one group consumed 1.2 g/kg of protein while the other consumed 2.4 g/kg. The higher protein group lost MORE fat mass and GAINED lean body mass compared to the lower protein group which lost less fat mass and did not gain lean body mass. 

It’s most ideally to consume around body weight or a bit over in a deficit in order to maximize lean tissue retention. This is typically around 1.0-1.2g/lb of BW. 😊

So be sure that you’ve put quality time in to growing your glutes and when you cut, make sure that you are consuming adequate protein 🩷

All things glute anatomy let’s go!📚

Save this post for brain gains📌

First, we’ve got the glute max. This is the biggest part of your booty. The glute max is the main hip extensor. The lower fibers do hip extension solely while the upper fibers also do external rotation and abduction. Think RDL’s, squats and lunges for lower fibers and hip thrusts, 45’s, and kickbacks for upper (w/external rotation). 

The glute medius (aka upper booty shelf) works to abduct (bring leg away from body) the hip and prevents the pelvis from tilting to the opposite side while standing on one leg. This means it works to stabilize while you are performing unilateral exercises. When I say you are training the stabilization component of the glute medius during unilateral work, this is what I mean. 

The glute medius has anterior and posterior fibers. The anterior fibers assist in hip internal rotation and flexing the hip. The posterior fibers assist in hip external rotation and extending the hip. 

Think kickbacks, abduction variations and unilateral work like step ups and lunges where there is a need for internal stabilization.

And then the minimus works alongside the medius in abduction. If you’re doing a kickback or side kick, you’re also working the minimus!

The best way to load a 45 isn’t actually going to be with free weights… 

It’s going to be with a BAND. And here’s why. 

The glutes have their best leverage in end range hip extension. And the band tension increases as you extend the hip. Therefore, you’re getting the greatest tension at the top where the glutes are the strongest when you use a band. 

This doesn’t mean to stop using free weights, I like using both! But if you haven’t tried the band version, give it a try! 🥳 If you choose to use free weights, make sure you hold it away from your chest as this increases the moment arm length to the glutes, making them work harder.

I often get asked what’s the most effective exercise order and how you know what order to set up your exercises in. 

First, the exercises you do in the beginning of the session are going to be the most effective in terms of recruiting the most motor units as there is little to no CNS fatigue present. If there is an exercise you are really trying to improve, start with that one. If there is a muscle you’re really trying to focus on, start with an exercise that targets that muscle. 

Second, it’s important to train shortened position exercises before lengthened. It’s a general rule, not an absolute. Short positions don’t accumulate as much central fatigue or muscle damage as lengthened positions do, so it’s best to start with shorts movements and do longer movements later on. It’s also most ideal to prioritize more short movements in your training for recovery 🩵

For example… 
You’d want to do a hip thrust before an RDL. 

Or a kickback before a squat. Unless those are movements you want to prioritize first.

I made this post in February of 2022 but we’re going to bring it back because I’m seeing this variation make its rounds again! 

The fiber orientation of the glute medius comes down off of the ilium and inserts onto the greater trochanter which means that in anatomical position it’s coming down at an angle at about 45 degrees.

So if you’re looking at someone from behind then the glute medius comes down like /  \

This is why a kickback that is effective for the glute medius comes from in front of the body, through hip extension with abduction.  That’s going to line up with the orientation of those fibers.

When you have the leg behind the body (there’s literally no good reason to do this at all) then you abduct from there you negate both a good line of pull for the glute medius fibers, but you also reduce the range of motion.  Taking away the longer muscle length that you get in the proper glute medius kickback.

Since the glutes appear to benefit from stretch mediated hypertrophy then taking away the more lengthened position means we’re literally making this exercise far less effective.  Notice in the stretch portion here of the reel that this is what is getting removed by doing that step behind kickback.

Doing that step over cable motion doesn’t offer up anything in the way of benefits for the glute medius and is actually a far less effective version because it doesn’t line up with the fibers of the glute medius and it takes away the longer muscle length that a proper kickback incorperates.

Squat deeper without butt wink!!!! 

When doing your squats you may notice that if you squat deep, you can end up getting a bit of “butt wink” which is also known as posterior pelvic tilt. This is when the pelvis tilts posteriorly and is often accompanied by a degree of lumbar flexion. 

This issue is more significant if you find it happening in the early stages of the eccentric squat motion because the degree of posterior tilt and lumbar flexion will then become become more prominent as the range of motion increases. 

There is many theories on why PPT occurs however the most logical one is running out of room at the joint which then causes the pelvis to tilt posteriorly in order to accommodate this issue. 

We want to keep a neutral spine and a stable/neutral pelvis for the musculature to work off of. In order to open up more room in the kinetic chain, a simple remedy for avoiding PPT is to allow the femur to externally rotate (point toes out) and to abduct at the hips.

This subtle change allows more room for the joints to move through and allows the pelvis room to function in neutrality in a deeper range of motion.

All things you need to know for building that booty shelf in under 30 seconds.

Side glutes, upper glutes, all of it. How do you build it? What exercises do you need to focus on? What muscles make up the side/upper glutes?

Let’s dive in👇

The side/upper glutes refer to the glute minimus, glute medius and upper fibers of the glute max. The medius/minimus are upper/side as the fibers wrap around (same for the iliac glute max fibers). 

So first you’ve got the upper fibers of the glute max that are going to contribute to that booty shelf look. The glute max is the largest glute muscle divided into the upper (iliac) and lower (sacrum & coccyx) regions. The upper glute region works to abduct and externally rotate the hip. 

Then you’ve got the medius and minimus. People tend to think these work separately of each other but they work together. They work to abduct (bring leg away from body) the hip and prevents the pelvis from tilting to the opposite side while standing on one leg.

So what movements target both the upper glute max and the medius and minimus? 

To target the upper glute max this is going to be bridges and thrusts with external rotation. You’ll also get some upper glute max in kickbacks and abduction variations. This is going to be more of a stable kickback where you’re kicking straight back. 

To target the medius and minimus, think kickbacks and abduction variations. 30 degree kickbacks, standing cable abduction, seated abduction… 

You’ll also get some glute medius/min work in unilateral movements where the medius has to shorten to stabilize the pelvis.

All of these movements contribute to that upper booty shelf look. 

What’s NOT going to target your upper glutes are lengthened movements like RDL’s and squats. 

It’s important to make sure you’re prioritizing these short length movements in your training to build those upper glutes.

While we now know you can’t really bias upper back from lats in a pull-down, you certainly can in a row! 

For more upper back ⬇️
✅Little bit of T-spine extension to disadvantage the lats 
✅Drive elbows back and behind body

For more lats⬇️
✅Limit t-spine extension by keeping a neutral spine as much as possible (too much t-spine extension will take lats out of active range) 
✅Don’t pull far past body (lumbar and thoracic fibers extend a bit posteriorly so you can pull a bit past body) 
✅Drive elbows to hips 

🔑Keep in mind that a lat row doesn’t mean there is no upper back involvement and that an upper back row doesn’t mean no lat involvement! You can just use different mechanics to bias MORE of one ☺️

You can actually *feel* the difference once you make these changes 🩷

Let’s talk about training hard/to failure… 

Training to failure and 3 RIR do not produce the same hypertrophic results❌ 

RIR = reps in reserve (reps you still could have gotten but were left)

The end of your set is where the greatest cross-bridging is occurring meaning that this is where the greatest amount of mechanical tension (driver for muscle growth) is being accumulated.

The last 5 reps done in a set to failure are what go towards muscle growth. 

So if you’re cutting off 3 of these…

You have a lot less reps going towards the hypertrophic response.

We also have studies showing a clear linear relationship with the fact that training to failure creates significantly more hypertrophy outcomes than 3 RIR.
DOI:10.51224/SRXIV.295
PMID: 34769755

1-2 RIR can get similar outcomes to training to failure but the meta-analysis above shows a bit better outcome from failure or even failing a rep.

Does this mean you should take every set to failure? No. 

Majority of people do tend to fall more in the 1-2 RIR range than failure, even when told to train to failure. And hypertrophic results are still made. 

You can do a mix of sets to failure and 1-2 RIR. 

❌Failure is not more fatiguing 
With proper volume and longer rest periods, this isn’t a valid argument against training to failure. It is much more fatiguing to stay away from failure and to train with higher volumes and shorter rest periods. Plus along with that fatigue, you’re not accumulating as much mechanical tension which means less hypertrophy. 

❌It’s not dangerous 
Yes, it can be if you’e neglecting your form to train to failure. Any time other muscles start to compensate for the fatigued muscles in a set and form begins to suffer, injury can occur. Injury can occur from bad form alone, you don’t need failure to incur an injury. I would never advise to train to failure with improper form. Once your form goes, the set is over. Starting with failure on machines is a good place to start because there’s a very low level of injury due to them being more stable. 

So for the best hypertrophic results, train to failure or pretty darn close to it😊

Creatine is one of the most researched supplements that has a ton of misinformation surrounding it. 

1. Creatine is created in our bodies. 
It’s legal and NOT a steroid in any way, shape or form. 

Creatine works by recycling ATP, which is the bodies source of energy. 

More creatine in muscles 💪 = more fuel ⛽️

2. Creatine is SAFE for males and females.
It’s not damaging to the kidneys when dosing instructions are followed.

It’s one of the most researched supplements and has been studied for a LONG time. 

PMID: 12701816.
PMID: 21399917.

3. Creatine helps build muscle, increases strength and athletic performance, improves recovery and has cognitive benefits. 

It helps even beyond the gym. Studies show that it improves short-term memory. 

PMID: 10731009.
PMID: 9390981.
PMID: 29704637.

4. Creatine does NOT cause weight gain. 
Creatine hydrates your cells. So this may appear as water weight, NOT fat. 

It’s stored intramuscular. 

I don’t recommend a loading phase because this is likely where you’re going to see more of that bloating effect. 

Take 3-5g daily.

HOW TO PROPERLY SIDE LATERAL RAISE⬇️

First, you want to be sure you’re working in the scapular plane for optimal deltoid output and shoulder health. To do this, bring the dumbbells in front of you and slightly lean forward with a split stance.

By working in the scapular plane, you’re allowing the shoulder to rotate upwards, elevate and slightly protract, which is what it is supposed to do. The traps can then better stabilize the scapula and can produce more output. 

Second, stop trying to “take your traps” out of it by holding your shoulders in retraction and bringing your arms directly out to the side. The traps work to stabilize the scapula. 

✅Slight forward lean/split stance to help work in scapular plane
✅Dumbbells in front of you 
✅Slight bend in elbows 
✅Push your hands towards the walls 

❌Don’t initiate with your traps/wrists 
❌Retract shoulders to “take traps out” 
❌Stand straight up (you’ll notice more stress in lower back this way as well as not be able to work in scapular plane as well)

Should you pause at the top or bottom⁉️

For certain movements, we can vary the tempo to challenge the target muscle where it has the most leverage. 

For lengthened movements, this will be at the bottom. 

For shortened movements, this will be at the top. 

For a glute leg press, squat and RDL we want to implement a pause at the bottom where the glute is the most lengthened and under the most tension. We are going to really be challenging those lower fibers of the glutes here. 

For a glute bridge/thrust, 45° glute raise and kickbacks, we want to implement a pause at the top where the glute is more shortened and under the most tension. We are really going to be challenging the upper fibers of the glutes here. 

Try adding pauses into these movements to really fire up your glutes and challenge them where they are under the most tension🔥🔥🔥🔥

Let’s simplify progressive overload! 

Progressive overload and mechanical tension are two principles NEEDED for muscle growth. But often, people don’t push themselves hard enough to increase the weight they’re using or they don’t have a clear view on what PO is. 

But let’s talk about what it is first.

Progressive overloading it increase your weights and/or reps over a period of time. 

For example, one session you may use 95lbs for 8 reps on RDLs. The next session you may do 95 lbs for 10 reps and then the following session, increase the weight to 100lbs for 6 reps. 

Progressive overload is NOT just adding more and more sets to increase volume. There’s a time and a place for increasing volume in a workout but the goal shouldn’t be to do more and more sets, but to gradually increase the weight and/or reps you’re doing in a set. 

This how we determine if adaptations are occurring (both neural and muscular) and if our training is working. 

Step 1: Increase the weight until you can do about 5-8 reps (I enjoy 4 reps as well) 
Step 2: Do this new weight until you can do 10-12 reps 
Step 3: Then increase again and do 5-8 reps
Repeat this and that’s progressive overload🔁✅ 

So instead of showing up to the gym and doing different movements each session, repeat the same movements and gradually add weight/reps over time.

Alright, so you don’t need a million curl variations to build some good biceps. A standard barbell, dumbbell or cable curl will do the job. The biceps grow best at mid range (greatest leverage at 90 degrees) so prioritize this position. 

We can also get good growth in the short position but the lengthened position is kind of meh because the biceps don’t seem to benefit much from longer lengths (pmid 32823490). But that doesn’t mean you won’t see any growth, but I’d recommend using this position the least.

Shoulder flexion = shortened 
Arms at sides = mid range 
Shoulder extension = lengthened

So focus most on short + mid range with occasional long lengths for some big juicy biceps 💪💪💪💪💪

Side note… the biceps do need some more recovery than other muscles so you don’t need to train them every single day for growth. A couple times a week is good!

You’ve probably seen a fair share of videos with misleading captions like “get rid of bra bulge”, “ do these exercises to snatch your waist!”, “target your back fat with these exercises!”

This is all incredibly misleading because you cannot spot reduce and fat loss routines don’t exist.

It’s a common misconception that when you go from building muscle to losing fat, you need to change your workouts. This is far from the truth. 

If you’re still wanting to maintain/build muscle in a fat loss phase, why would you stop doing what built you that muscle in the first place? 

When it comes to losing body, fat, diet is key. Yet we have a bunch of influencers running around claiming that fat loss routines exist, and you can target body fat with certain exercises. 

For a successful fat loss phase where you’re still maintaining/building muscle mass, you want to decrease your calories so that you’re in a deficit (make sure it’s adherable), keep protein high(about 1.0-1.2g/lb of BW), and train the SAME way you did when your goal was muscle growth. 

High reps don’t cause more fat loss. They just increase fatigue and make it harder to recover. Even in a fat loss phase, you still want to keep your reps low to moderate and keep training volume relatively the same.

Fat loss routines don’t exist and high reps don’t cause more fat loss. The end.🩷

For those who really want to build muscle mass and get stronger… 

Good quality training is BORING. 

Good quality training is redundant. 

Good quality training is what works! 

1. Stick to the same program for 6-8 weeks (or even longer if you’d like) 
It’s important to stick to the same program for a few months to allow for progressive overload to occur and to improve upon those movements. If you’re constantly changing things up, how will you know if you’re making progress?

2. Stick to the basics, not made up IG influencer stuff

5. Training hard/to failure
I’ve talked about training to failure a lot and how I’m a proponent of it but it’s important to train in a way that challenges you and increase your weights over time for progressive overload and growth to occur. 

6. Take longer rest periods (2-3 min for working sets) rather than short rest periods (30-60s). I’ve also talked about longer rest periods and how we actually see greater hypertrophy with long rest periods than short. It allows for central fatigue to subside between sets and therefore greater motor unit recruitment. 

If you’re bored in the gym, this is a good thing😁

After years of training and training people, here is the model that I’ve found that works most efficiently for training glutes (and all other muscles) that also prioritizes recovery! 

1. Start with short movements(2-3) or ones you want to prioritize:
You’ll always be strongest at the beginning of your session. So if there’s a movement you really want to focus on, start with this. I typically recommend starting with short movements because these movements are least fatiguing and it’s ideal to work from a short to lengthened position (general rule not set in stone). 

2.  Use your first 2-3 sets (depending on if you’re doing 3 or 4 sets for that movement) as warm ups and take your last set to failure. You’ll likely need more warm ups in the beginning of your session but may only need 2 towards the end. Sometimes I’ll do 1 set to failure, sometimes 2. But typically it’s 2-3 warm ups and 1 hard set to failure. 

3. Use descending reps. I’ve utilized many rep schemes throughout my years of training but I’ve always found descending reps to be the best. This is where you start with higher reps and gradually decrease, while increasing the weight. For example, 4x10, 8, 6, 4 and 4x 12, 10, 8, 6 are some of my favorites. Or 3x8, 6, 4 or 3x 10,8,6 if you’re doing 3 sets. I have found that people are more likely to increase their weight and challenge themselves more using this method, as opposed to giving them 3x15 or 4x10. The last set will be the heaviest and taken to failure. 

4. End with lengthened movements (1-2). Lengthened movements are the most fatiguing and hardest to recover from so that’s why it’s best to place them at the end and to also do less of these than short. Usually 1-2 in a workout. These can be unilateral or bilateral. If I’m doing 2, I’ll do 1 bilateral and 1 unilateral. 

I hope this helps you with your glute training!!! These methods can also be applied to ANY muscle.

Let’s chat about ineffective training vs. effective training.

My workouts looked a lot like this when I first started. And I still got results. And you will too. But, I had to do a ton of volume to get the results I did and spent way too long in the gym. 

Short rest periods + training far from failure = the need for A LOT more volume to make good progress.

Instead, you can literally cut this volume in half and take longer rest periods (2-3 min) and train to failure/close to it.

Rather than doing a bunch of 4x15, lower those reps and train to failure. 

I personally enjoy descending reps where you’re increasing the weight each set as the reps drop. This is going to force you to pick up more weight each set. As the reps drop, each set will get harder and then the last set should be taken to failure or close to it. The preceding sets help warm you up for this. Combine this method with longer rest periods and you’re golden 💛 

You don’t need to spend hours in the gym doing a ton of exercises with a ton of reps and sets to get good results. 

And while intensifiers like supersets, drop sets, etc. can be utilized in efficient programming, they’re still more fatiguing and therefore should be utilized sparingly and with lower reps. 

Inefficient training approaches are everywhere. Watch out for them.

Okay, so here’s a topic that goes with the question “how do I lose fat and keep my glutes?” Well, you don’t. Unless your glutes are pure muscle (not the case), but the more muscle you have on your glutes, the less likely you are to “lose your glutes”. 

But, you can see here I have LESS glutes with LOWER body fat. And while I’d like to have glutes in pic 3 with leanness of pic 1, that’s just not happening lol.

The leaner you are, the less overall body fat you have, therefore the smaller your glutes are going to be compared to when you have a higher body fat and have more fat on your glutes.

When it comes to dieting after a building phase, it’s important to do so in a way that preserves muscle. This entails keeping protein high (body weight or 1.2ish grams per lb of body weight) and doing a more moderate deficit and slowly decreasing calories over time.

So while you can’t determine if you lose body fat from your glutes or not, you can focus on building quality glute muscle over a long period of time and then diet to preserve muscle mass. But the more fat you have on your glutes, the more likely you are to “lose” them in a diet phase. Unless you’re just genetically blessed with a fat @$$ and a small waist. That ain’t me though. 🤪

Let’s talk about training hard/to failure… 

Training to failure and 3 RIR do not produce the same hypertrophic results❌ 

RIR = reps in reserve (reps you still could have gotten but were left)

The end of your set is where the greatest cross-bridging is occurring meaning that this is where the greatest amount of mechanical tension (driver for muscle growth) is being accumulated.

The last 5 reps done in a set to failure are what go towards muscle growth. 

So if you’re cutting off 3 of these…

You have a lot less reps going towards the hypertrophic response.

We also have studies showing a clear linear relationship with the fact that training to failure creates significantly more hypertrophy outcomes than 3 RIR.
DOI:10.51224/SRXIV.295
PMID: 34769755

1-2 RIR can get similar outcomes to training to failure but the meta-analysis above shows a bit better outcome from failure or even failing a rep.

Does this mean you should take every set to failure? No. 

Majority of people do tend to fall more in the 1-2 RIR range than failure, even when told to train to failure. And hypertrophic results are still made. 

You can do a mix of sets to failure and 1-2 RIR. 

❌Failure is not more fatiguing 
With proper volume and longer rest periods, this isn’t a valid argument against training to failure. It is much more fatiguing to stay away from failure and to train with higher volumes and shorter rest periods. Plus along with that fatigue, you’re not accumulating as much mechanical tension which means less hypertrophy. 

❌It’s not dangerous 
Yes, it can be if you’e neglecting your form to train to failure. Any time other muscles start to compensate for the fatigued muscles in a set and form begins to suffer, injury can occur. Injury can occur from bad form alone, you don’t need failure to incur an injury. I would never advise to train to failure with improper form. Once your form goes, the set is over. Starting with failure on machines is a good place to start because there’s a very low level of injury due to them being more stable. 

So for the best hypertrophic results, train to failure or pretty darn close to it😊

Short rest periods + training far from failure = the need for A LOT more volume to make good progress.

Instead, you can literally cut this volume in half and take longer rest periods (3-5 min) and train to failure/close to it.

Rather than doing a bunch of 4x15-20, lower those reps and train to failure. You’ll feel a ton better in terms of recovery.

I personally enjoy descending reps where you’re increasing the weight each set as the reps drop. This is going to force you to pick up more weight each set. As the reps drop, each set will get harder and then the last set should be taken to failure or close to it. The preceding sets help warm you up for this.

And while intensifiers like supersets, drop sets, etc. can be utilized in efficient programming, they’re still more fatiguing and therefore should be utilized sparingly and with lower reps. 

It’s also not ideal to pair unilateral with bilateral and vice versa because you always have one side that is going to end up being more fatigued than the other and over time this can lead to imbalances. 

The overuse of lengthened movements is something I often see and these should be used more sparingly compared to shortened due to how fatiguing they are.

Alright don’t get mad at me, get mad at the data. 

We now have 2 large reviews looking at whether or not women’s training was impacted by their menstrual cycle.

It is often thought that hormonal fluctuations women encounter have a negative impact on their MC and they should train differently during their cycle/cycle sync.

It’s important to note that it’s hard to predict exactly where you’re at in your cycle so setting up a resistance training program based on this is even more difficult. Proper menstrual phase detection methods are important. The variance in individuals and even between menstrual cycles further makes it difficult to create a program based around one’s cycle that is fully accurate. This review concluded that the studies surrounding phase-based training have a lot of shortcomings and that is greatly pertains to the individual.

Both reviews found that overall, strength, performance and long term adaptations were not impacted by the MC. 

 “Strength-related measures appear to be minimally altered (g≤0.35) by the fluctuations in ovarian sex hormones that occur during the menstrual cycle”. PMID: 32456980.

This review concluded that…
“When reviewing the evidence as a whole—and the methodological shortcomings therein—we propose it is highly premature to conclude that short-term fluctuations in ovarian hormones appreciably influence acute exercise performance or longer-term adaptations to resistance training”. And that training according to your cycle is not an evidence based approach and more research is needed. PMID: 37033884

Another review looked at the effects of the menstrual cycle and oral contraceptives on performance and hypertrophy and concluded “Overall, the consensus of this review suggests that the impact of MC and OC use on various physiological outcomes is small or, in many cases, nonexistent” PMID: 37823207. So good news for those who ask about BC and its impact on training.

For the last 6-8 months or so, I’ve had zero gym motivation. I truly hated going to the gym each day and I had to force myself to go.

Did we all do this kinda stuff or was it just me?😂😂😂😂 

Nah, I still see a lot of made up stuff on here as well. And I call it out because I used to do weird made up stuff as well. So here’s me calling myself out lol. 

I was always trying to reinvent the wheel and do exercises that looked cool. My routine was never consistent and I was always changing up exercises. 

Yes, I made progress. But I also was in the gym for hours doing a ton of high volume work. Whereas now, I spend 45-60 minutes in the gym repeating the same exercises I’ve done for months. Not only have I made great progress, but I also recover well. 

So if you see an exercise on IG that looks cool but the person isn’t actually explaining the reason for performing the exercise, I’d probably skip it and stick to the basics. The basics are always BEST.

Awesome exercise but not the exact same as Bulgarian❌

A Bulgarian split squat (assuming you’re not holding onto anything to make it more stable) is more glute medius due to the need for stabilization.

When a unilateral movement requires more internal stabilization, the glute medius is going to shorten to stabilize the pelvis. 

If we want to train the stability component of the glute medius, it’s best to choose a movement that requires is more highly coordinated, which is why I am not holding onto anything for balance. 

The glute medius does the stability work while the glute max is doing the dynamic work here.

A single leg press is going to be glute max due to the stability offered up by this machine therefore the glute medius does not have to shorten to stabilize.

These are two really good unilateral exercises that can both be utilized in your training for different reasons! But aren’t the exact same.

How I warm up for leg day (well actually ALL my training days) can be kind of controversial so let’s talk about it… 

I don’t dynamic stretch. 

I don’t static stretch. 

I don’t do a bunch of cardio… 
(Not bad things (except static)-they have application, just not what I do) 

And while a little bit of cardio (low intensity 5-10 min) and dynamic stretches prior to your workout are not bad at all, I just don’t utilize them for warm ups. We know that static stretching pre training is legit bad for hypertrophy so don’t do this❌ 

So what do I do then? 

I use WARM UP SETS. These are lighter weight/bit higher rep sets of the exercises I’m doing that day. 

These sets do a few things… 

1. Warm up my muscles 
2. Prepare my nervous system for that motor pattern 
3. Feedback on how I’m feeling mentally/physically 
4. Give a good idea to what my top set is going to be (set I take to failure) 

People always overcomplicate these sets even though it’s actually quite simple and there’s no super scientific method to it! 

Start with a lighter weight. Aim for around 10-12 reps. Increase the weight. Decrease the reps. Then increase the weight and decrease the reps again, until you feel ready for your final set to failure. Typically you’ll need 2-3 and then 1 set to failure. 

I like to use a rep scheme like 12, 10, 8, 6 and 10, 8, 6, 4. 

The last set will typically always vary as it’s the set you take to failure. 

I’ve used this methods for years in my own training as well as in my programming and have found that people are more likely to pick up heavier weights rather than sticking to the same weight for each set and also more likely to challenge themselves. 💪

Main takeaway: 
⬆️weight ⬇️ reps each set

How to REALLY target upper glutes 

I see so many exercises saying they target upper glutes yet they aren’t actually training the functions of the upper glutes which are hip extension WITH abduction and external rotation. 

I saw a post this morning where someone was sitting on a bench and bending over and calling it upper glutes. No wonder y’all are so confused lol. Argh, I digress. 

So if you really want to crush your upper glutes in hip extension, try this. 

So the key here is to train external rotation and LOAD it. This is why the cuff is around my foot, not my ankle. 

You want to drive back into hip extension and as you’re doing so, think of turning your toe outwards and driving your knee towards the ceiling. This is really going to hit the upper glutes due to doing hip extension along with external rotation and loading that motion. 

I am using the bench for stability, you can do it without. But you want the cuff around your foot rather than your ankle so that you’re actually loading external rotation, not just doing that motion. 

Give it a try and let me know!!!

Step over kickback for upper glutes?? 

This is making its rounds again so let’s talk about it!! 

The fiber orientation of the glute medius comes down off of the ilium and inserts onto the greater trochanter which means that in anatomical position it’s coming down at an angle at about 45 degrees.

So if you’re looking at someone from behind then the glute medius comes down like /  \

This is why a kickback that is effective for the glute medius comes from in front of the body, through hip extension with abduction.  That’s going to line up with the orientation of those fibers.

When you have the leg behind the body (there’s literally no good reason to do this at all) then you abduct from there you negate both a good line of pull for the glute medius fibers, but you also reduce the range of motion.  Taking away the longer muscle length that you get in the proper glute medius kickback.

Since the glutes appear to benefit from stretch mediated hypertrophy then taking away the more lengthened position means we’re literally making this exercise far less effective.  Notice in the stretch portion here of the reel that this is what is getting removed by doing that step behind kickback.

Doing that step over cable motion doesn’t offer up anything in the way of benefits for the glute medius and is actually a far less effective version because it doesn’t line up with the fibers of the glute medius and it takes away the longer muscle length that a proper kickback incorporates.

So is it bad??? no. Is it most effective for targeting the gmed? No. 

I recommend the version I show in this video or check out the other kickback post I made the other day that loads external rotation 🔥

People will often say that rounding your back will cause the glutes to activate more but this simply isn’t true. 

✅Rounding your back can be a good teaching tool to teach someone to drive their glutes into the pad but eventually you want to transition to using a neutral spine.

A round back is often cued because spine extension has been said to activate the erector spinae more however having “less” erector spinae doesn’t mean “more glutes”. 

If you’re feeling a lot of low back, start with the round back version and eventually move onto the neutral spine version with a good rom that fully shortens the glutes. When you come up too high (common, more common with neutral spine), this is where you’ll recruit more erectors. 

If you compare the hip extension achieved in the rounded back version to the neutral spine version, you’ll see that it’s limited with the rounded back. I can achieve greater shortening of the glutes with a neutral spine. 

The glutes also need a stable and neutral spine to have the best position to extend the hip. 

Also a study done in 2015, A Comparison of Gluteus Maximus, Biceps Femoris, and Vastus Lateralis EMG Amplitude for the Barbell, Band, and American Hip Thrust Variations, looked at EMG activation in various hip thrust variations. AHT is done with PPT (what we’re doing in the rounded version) and this had LESS glute activation than a barbell hip thrust (neutral spine). So we see this in EMG data as well.

If you’re struggling to feel your glutes and feel a lot of low back, try the rounded back version to learn to engage your glutes by driving them into the pad. 

Then transition to a neutral spine✅

When I posted this in my story, I got a ton of questions about how it works! 

It’s a 45 but you’re using a cable (can also add bands to each side) for resistance. This machine was created 10/10 because the resistance profile is favorable to where the glutes are under the most tension (at the top-descending resistance profile). 

The cable is already set further away from you, making it so the moment arm is longer to the glutes and therefore they work harder. So no need to worry about holding a plate out in front of you.

Alright, read the caption before you come for me👇👇 

I like all these things too and they’re not BAD but…

It’s a common myth that intensifiers like supersets, trisets, drop sets, finishers etc. are better for muscle growth than just doing straight sets. And this is NOT true. 

While these have application, (timesavers, enjoyment factor, alleviate redundancy/boredom…) your best bet for muscle growth is always going to be straight sets where you’re progressively overloading and using proper rest. 

With intensifiers, you’re just accumulating more fatigue in the set. This can make training less productive. 

On the second or third exercise in a drop set or superset, you’re going to have a lot of fatigue going into this exercise. Therefore, you won’t be able to train as hard, go as heavy and it will be harder to progressively overload over time, compared to doing it as a straight set. 

Now there’s a better way to implement supersets and drop sets. I personally would never recommend a tri set, there’s just waaaay too much fatigue and the goal is not to exhaust yourself in the gym. Proper rest periods are needed to hypertrophy and by the time you get to the third exercise, you’re going to be exhausted and also can increase injury risk depending on the exercise. 

For supersets and drop sets, keep the reps LOWER. So instead of doing 10+ reps in a superset on each exercise, stick to something like 4-8 to lessen fatigue. For a drop set, perform it on your last set to failure and then make small decreases in weight where you’re only getting a few reps (3-4) to increase the amount of effective reps you’re getting in that set.

When it comes to training for muscle growth, we want to keep fatigue as low as we can to allow for good recovery and to make training as productive as we can. 

So yes, intensifiers are okay to add in to your training but I would limit them and keep reps low👌

The most efficient way to train for growth is straight sets, training to failure/close to it and progressively overloading over time. If you want to add a finisher, drop set or super set in, go for it. I just wouldn’t make this the focus or overdo it!🩷

How many abduction exercises do you need y’all? 

Just one, one will do lol. 

All 4 of these exercises are doing the same thing… it’s hip flexion + abduction… 

And this same motion can be trained on the abduction machine which also offers up more stability 👍 and you can also lean forwards more to disadvantage the piriformis a bit. 

Also, if you’re doing all of these in the same workout, you’re going to end up with some pretty rough sciatic nerve pain. While it’s ok to train hip flexion + abduction for glutes, this does involve a lot of piriformis and over time, this can cause sciatic nerve pain as this muscle is very close to the sciatic nerve.

Ever had that low back/upper butt pinching pain? Yeah, me too. That’s it. And too much abduction in hip flexion can cause that over time. 

So you definitely just want to do one exercise training this motion and to be aware of overdoing it. ❌

But honestly, just use the hip abduction machine. It’s a better set up, easier, more stable and just overall better lol.

And if you need more rom (will depend on machine and individual), you can just add some yoga pads on each side. 

No hate to this creator. But you really want to be careful with overdoing this motion.

Good quality training is boring and redundant. But that doesn’t engage. 

99.9% of the time, the basics are going to get you the results you want. Along with patience and consistency.

People are constantly trying to reinvent the wheel and overcomplicate things. I’ve even done this! When in reality, the best exercises have already been invented.

It’s often forgotten how much genetics play a role in someone’s overall physique. Yes, you can absolutely change your body through losing fat and gaining muscle, but you can’t out-train genetics. There are certain body types that cannot be trained for.

Talk about 2+ hours in the gym and 833783 movements 🥵 

I don’t know how I did this y’all 😂 But I can tell you now that I’ve changed so much since then. 

I used to spend hours in the gym, chasing the “burn”, exhausting myself, doing a million exercises and feeling as thought this is what it takes to get/stay in shape. And I promise you, this is not it. 

I rarely took rest days. I thought if I took one I’d lose progress or be missing out on it. I literally thought I had to work out 7x per week in order to get results. And I was exhausted! 

Thankfully, my mindset has changed so much. The gym is no longer my entire life, it’s part of my life. I train 4-5x per week, do half the amount of movements I used to do and I genuinely look forward to my off days. I am not afraid of taking days off, I don’t exhaust myself in the gym and I train in a way that is productive and also that I enjoy. 

I don’t change up my exercises constantly. I don’t add a ton of burners or finishers to every workout just to “feel” more. I don’t do a bunch of high reps anymore. 

I focus on my form. I train with intensity. I focus on each movement, rather than just moving to the next to get more done. I train with intent. I pick 4-5 quality movements and focus on getting stronger on them over time. I take rest periods. 

My mindset around fitness has completely changed for the better! 

I promise you don’t need to exhaust yourself every session in order to make progress.

“Why do I feel quads in my back leg??” 

Okay so I have seen this video go around and this guy was catching some heat in the comments so I want to address it. 

ESPECIALLY because I always get asked “why do I feel Bulgarians in my back quad?”

So he’s correct in when he says this isn’t really more glutes and here’s why. 

She’s getting a lot of quads in that rear leg. The back leg is put into hip extension and the rec fem is lengthened. When the back leg is really high, the rec fem is really lengthened. So as you get to the bottom of the rep, the rec fem continues to get longer and longer, therefore the front leg has to then compensate for this which is why the knee pulls back. 

This can also be due to having a bench that’s too high. 
The back leg should be high enough so that you can get maximum range of motion without that knee pulling back.

It’s ideal to stop at around 90 degrees to keep the focus on glutes and avoid over lengthening that rec fem. Plus the deeper you go into hip flexion, the more adductors you’ll get as well!!

When you hold the weight at your chest for a 45° glute raise, you decrease the length of the moment arm making it so that you are working harder to hold the weight and the glutes aren’t being maximally loaded. 

The most optimal way to load the 45 degree glute raise is going to be with the weight out in front of you versus at your chest. This has to do with the length of the moment arm.

Moment arm = the distance between the the hip joint and the load. 

Holding the weight in front of you increases the moment arm allowing for more tension on the glutes and maximal loading. This is going to be a harder variation that causes the glutes to work harder. 

Another great option to load a 45 that will force you to have a longer moment arm is a barbell!🩷

Yep, it’s a legit exercise! It’s a brutal one🥵 

This is a Bulgarian split squat with rotation🤎 

So why the rotation?

The rotation is the benefit since the hip is a ball and socket joint, and most people lack good rotation at the hip. 

Why is this important?  Because the glutes extend the hip but we need good rotation in order to have a place to extend FROM. 

The other benefit here is that the upper glute division is lengthened a bit more in the rotation and biases it just a bit here.

It is important to make sure you’re actually rotating from the hip and not just twisting your torso. 

This means holding the weight CONTRALATERAL. You need to be able to reach over to the other foot for the rotation. This is going be the actual rotation that lengthens the upper glutes a bit more. 

You can also do it with a cable for more fun🥰
